Besides those two already mentioned, the following persons were also early settlers; viz: Phrez Blake; Norton Blake; Henry Shoemaker; Thomas Lock; David Martin; Wm. M'Entaffer and George Seiner. At the first election, held in the township, there were just enough votes to form a board, viz. five.

Smithfield is now equally as well improved, according to the time of its settlement, as any other [place in the county]. It is doubtless, destined to keep pace with any other in all the elements of wealth and beauty.
Chapter XIII

Fairfield Township is in the northwest corner of the county, and is six miles square. It is the most hilly one. The land is considerably broken in places, but the soil is very generally quite rich and easily tilled. Fairfield was the last township in the county to fill up with settlers. This was owing to its distance from Fort Wayne from the St. Joseph river and from the county seat. Since the country has been settled up and plank and railroads have been built, it is equally as favored with conveniences of all kinds as the other townships. To the lover of the picturesque it will be the most inviting township in the county, when its long slopes, rugged bluffs, deep ravines with limpid rills, and its lake shores shall be properly improved.

The very first settlers in the township were of the family of Story. Could I have seen them perhaps they would have furnished me stories for this chapter. As it is however my story about this township is short. Of these Storys there are Augustus, Frederick, Willard, George and Samuel. But as a good story is always acceptable these, being, so far as I am informed, all good, their number is really an advantage to the township and county. R. R. Lounsbery was another early settler, he having sold out in Wilmington and settled in Fairfield quite early. Here, I believe, he found a grave. Wilbur Powell, William and Isaac Wilsey, D. Rager, Esq., Hiram Thomas, Phillip Gushwa, John Shook, Henry and Leonard
Hartman, and Miles Allen, were also all early settlers in the township. Others may have settled there as soon, but I am not appraised of any others. I have received no incidents of the early days of the township and perhaps, as this was the last one to be settled there may be no very remarkable incidents.

The township was organized in the spring of 1844, there being then but six voters, if I am correctly informed. There are now two hundred forty voters in it. This may give some idea of its rapid settlement. Fairfield Center is the only village in its bounds and there is but little prospect of its becoming a city very soon. The railroad passing through a little south of the township line draws the trade to the villages on the road. A few years will no doubt make good its name, and fair fields and beautiful dwellings will be seen in every part of the township.

And now fellow citizens I am about to close my sketches. The resources of our country are only beginning to be developed. We have all the elements of temporal prosperity at hand. The soil of our county taking it as a whole is decidedly good. The timber is excellent. We have railroad facilities through almost the very center of the county, and throughout its entire length. These facilities will perhaps be increased by the building of another road hereafter. We have abundant water power in the St. Joseph river and the several creeks passing through the county, and where there is any lack in this respect the power of steam is supplying it. Good school houses are being built by most of the townships in the several school districts. The Auburn Union school and the Newville Academy present opportunities for higher attainments in science. Good churches are being erected all over the county by Evangelical denominations and our citizens generally are moral, enterprising, industrious and religiously disposed. The health of our county has greatly improved for a few years past and will, no doubt, still improve as the country is cleared up and the marshes drained. Let us be grateful for the advantages we enjoy, and strive to act well our part as citizens and as christians. If we live forgetful of our duty to God, to one another, or to our fellow men at large, no amount of temporal prosperity can make us truly blest. May God bless you all.

div.head: Documents MEXICAN WAR LETTERS
div.p: The letters here printed were written by young men from Carroll County , Indiana, who served in the Mexican War. Robert H. Milroy and Samuel L. Milroy were sons of General Samuel Milroy, a pioneer who lived on a farm a short distance east of Delphi. He was one of the most prominent men of his section of Indiana. He died in 1845. Robert H. went to Mexico as the captain of his company. He was then about thirty years of age. Samuel L., a few years younger than Robert, became a lieutenant and later a captain. Dr. E. M. H. Beck was a friend of the Milroy family, also from Delphi. After his return to Indiana he was married to Miss Frances M. Milroy. Dr. Beck served through the Civil War as a physician and surgeon, and later practiced medicine in Delphi for several years. After the Mexican War, Robert H. Milroy lived at Renssalaer, Indiana, where he practiced law. He went to the Civil war as colonel of the Ninth Indiana Regiment. Samuel L. Milroy made his home on the old farm, entered and cleared by his father General Milroy, to the time of his death. William E. Pearsons, who writes one of the letters, was a friend of Dr. Beck and the Milroy family. He also became a captain while in Mexico. Mrs. A. A. Grimes was a sister of Robert H. and Samuel L. Milroy, and the wife of Dr. Samuel Grimes of Delphi. James Milroy, a brother of Robert H. and Samuel L., was at home on the farm during the Mexican War as the letters indicate.
Dr. E. M. H. Beck to Frances M. Milroy.

I can not let the opportunity pass without writing a few lines, in regard to matters. … I am well enough satisfied with my situation, but miss your society very much. I shall be so uncivilized & have such long whiskers when I return, that my recognition will not be desirable. I am well regarded as a practitioner, am in for an appointment if there is vaction'y [vacancy] I wish you could step down & and see how we live, & I think if Robert goes home on a furlough for his health, you had better come along and bring your sewing with you. The bad diet is all that keeps Rob down & he will get well enough after while—II try & get him to take a small trip—that will recruit him. You must not be alarmed, he is in the best of care. Saml's health is good
except a brash occasionally. Pe[a]rsons and myself thrives pretty well, I assure you. I often think of the big spring & would give at times a good deal for a gourd full of it. It is one year of domestic happiness thrown away—but what matters it. it is as it is—and Il accomplish what I came for1—or fail by bad luck. I am more for Texas now than I used to be, & hope to see the day before five years that I will live in some part of it. I am trying to cultivate a better military Spirit here but its a bad place—the Boys generally are tired of it. Their chivalric spirit having entirely subsided. Nothing doing & hard living they say— 'tis the sameness tires them. Frank, we have the finest Moonlight here & cool air imaginable, resembling the past only in those particulars, but not in confidential chats, & (soothe sayings) a sprinkling of which still hankers on the principles to be retained. I wait with patientes to hear a word from you—twill revive the spirit in a lonesome hour if nothing else, & such a revival would be fine for its lonesome I assure you. Nothing is to be seen but the Boys lying around in the shade fighting flies, & wishing to get home. A newspaper is worshipped. & a paper from you occasionally would read well, & a little penciling on the margins would not be detected. I hope you will answer immediately. (Frank Milroy)
div.trailer: Excuse the half sheet ft hurry. Il write more at length in my next if desirable.

div.p: Samuel L. Milroy to James Milroy.

address.addrLine: Camp at the Mouth of the Rio Grand

div.p: Bob and me are both enjoying good health at present. Robert is almost as fleshy as he was when he left home, and I am a great deal more so. I weigh now 152 and when I left [New] Albany I only weighed 144. This climate agrees very well with me but it has made sad havoc among the Wabash Invincibles. There has been 8 died out of the Company and upwards of 20 discharged from diseaz. But it is not to be wondered at taken into consideration the places we have been stationed at and the provisions that we have which are not fit for the sick to eat.

We have been stationed here at the Mouth fo[r] nea[r] two mortths and no hopes for getting farther or having to fight the infernal Mexicans. if we had Field Officers that were worth a sent [cent] and new their duty, we might have been at the taking of Monterey, but as long as we have Jackasses at the head of the Regiment we will remain on this sand bank.

I suppose that you have had all the particulars of that Battle and Old Rough and Ready (Old slow and Easy, as we call him) puffed in the newspapers as a second Bonapart in his management of that siege but if it had not been for the superior management of Genl. Worth and the bravery of the volunteers, Old Zeek would have been totally defeated and had to pulled for our side of the line, the volunteers have all the glory
of that Battle, they fought like young Devils. I wish we had been in it darn it.

I have not received my commission as Lieut, from [Governor] Whit-comb so I have went into the ranks again Davis has not got his discharge signed yet. I don't think that he will go home yet a while, there is nothing worth writing transpires in our camp or I should have written oftener.

I should like to hear how you get along with the farm and how much wheat you have got in. You have a great deal of hard work to do I know, more than you ought to do yourself you ought to have a hand. I almost wish that I was there, but am not sorry for the step I have taken. persevere Jim. I writ home by Tailor and sent two strings of shells to Martha, but I have reason to believe that he was lost at sea I also writ a letter to Morg Wilson he has never answered it take the liberty of twiching his nose for me if you pleaz You must all write. And Jim you particularly, giv my respects to all of our friends. Your Brother, & Mother, your afectionate Son.
Robert H. Milroy to James Milroy.

Well Jim, Sam has made a mistake and skiped this page [second of four-page sheet] and I have concluded to put something on it just to keep it from looking bad as I have nothing to say of consequence as there has nothing happened since I last wrote you worth mentioning except that two more of my boys have died. Michael Bell and Thomas Landrum the first the 12th inst & the other on the 13th. And 12 more of my men have been discharged. … My company now consists of 61, officers and all. I have sent 6 men to the hospital at Matamoras. We will probably remain at this place [Mouth of Rio Grande] for some time for the reason that our old Jackass of a Colonel gets at the rate of $936.00 more per annum for guarding a separate post than if he was with the brigade under the Brig. Genl. this is a miserable cheerless place & the men are getting homesick & dying from inactivity. We all wish that the devil had our file officers from Genl. Taylor down. Frank Graham has just come into my Markee from Monteray. The Texans are all disbanded and Charles and John McCarty have gone home by land. Frank is on his way to the U. S. & Cincinatti they were all in the hottest of the battle—This is the 19th and is pay day and we will [draw] the first pay that we have had since we left N. Albany . Take good care of Mother, and write soon.
E. M. H. Beck to Frances M. Milroy.

div.salute: The top o' the morning to you, Frank:
div.p:
How d'ye flourish? Faith an I thot ye'd forgot your auld friend out-. right. I did nae hae a line frae yer sweet han so lang time, which drew
a tear or twa frae me 'ee (Burns)—I never felt happier in my life than day before yesterday after a long absence from bouth you and my Father (for whom I had such anxiety) when 1 reed a long letter from each, containing glad tidings of great joy, health &c, &c. I honestly assure you although you did not receive them, I have written at least one letter per week, to some of your family since my arrival in Mexico, I wrote during Saml's illness. Although I had but a feint hope of recovery at the time, I since told you he had completely recovered. You never saw him so lusty as now. This News, you will have public a few days in advance of this as I wrote to the Republican. We are all anxiety yet. Our Regt. Boarded a steamer yesterday for Camargo, but that instant, [came] an express from the mouth of the river, stating that a large body of troops (Mexican) was within a few miles up stream & meditating an attack— The boats turned and went post haste. The enemy had gone, would not venture an attack. I just reached home, bid good bye to our boys—for they join the 3d Ohio Regt. at Camargo & go to Genl. Taylor's relief if possible. They are determined to cut through or fall. I hope they will get to him, for they are attempting to starve him out. They have had a hard battle, he is not whiped although surrounded by 20 or 30,000 of their yellow hides.

Wm. E. P. [Pearsons] stays here a few days turning over property to the new commandant, then follows. Although we made every effort for my going along, they would not spare me here—as we have about 100 more patients.

Genl. Minion of Mexican army sends us word that he will enter our city soon & if we want to spare our throats—to leave for his rule will spare none. We sent him word to drive us out. We now have 800 raw Missipi. Volt & 2 citizens companys and 2 [companies] of 80 each convalescent Hospital patients purposely detained one comp of which I com-m'd, & you ought to see me drill them on this house top. You'r mistaken if you think I wont fight. If compelled to leave, we will attempt to run everything into Fort Brown , & never give that up. What an excitement in town. We lay on our arms. Nearly all the native citizens have left the city for a while, business nearly suspended, but should Scott get our express, he will send to our assistance. We can hear nothing from Taylor—they have cut off the express, but the reason we think that he gave them the worst of the battle, is, that the natives, here, are not rejoicing— if anything, are a little down in the mouth. Rob is very anxious for a fight—indeed all the boys are on tiptoe to go through, when they know that under the circumstances they will have to remain some time after the year expires. Cap. Pe[a]rsons & I will not promise when we will be home—I like the excitement, & can I continue in employment, will see it out, if its a lifetime. & unless it gets remarkably healthy, I can get employment.

Capt. is in fine health and spirits—the men are all in good health likewise. Such is a hint of the times in matamoras just now. Today is Sunday—but you would not think so if you were here. I have written all that is of interest, relative to the situation of things.

closer.salute: Give my love to all. Ustede Sempre—

div.p: William E. Pearsons to Frances M. Milroy.
Your letter of March 1st came to hand a few days since and was read with much pleasure—

My chief source of pleasure and pastime during this campaign has been my correspondence with old friends and acquaintances—Every one [letter] I receive brings to my mind the difference existing between a soldiers and citizens life—Not that I am the least homesick or dissatisfied but the remembrance of old scenes and friends furnishes a pastime for the many unoccupied hours of a soldier which are idled away without business, books, or friends, to occupy his mind—But a truce to sentimental-isms and less [let's] rite the news—Since I wrote you last we have moved our quarters from Matamoras to this place (Monterey)—Our march was a pleasant one—Dr. Beck remained in Matamoras in the Genl. Hospital— I received a letter from him yesterday he is in good spirits—

About two weeks ago Samuel and myself visited the glorious battle field of Buena Vista—Genl. Lain went with us all over the battlefield, and pointed out to us the different positions of each corps of troops on the field. We you are aware were not in the fight—If we had been I believe the unjust charge of cowardice would never have been circulated against the Indiana Volunteers—Unjust it certainly is for the 2d Indiana Regiment actually done the hardest fighting that was done upon the field and fled only when they were ordered to do so by their cowardly old fool of a Colonel, who after he had given this order joined the Mississippi . Regt. and fought under the colors of another State—telling them that his own Right had fled like cowards from the field and denied having given them the order to retreat. He ought to have a mill-stone tied to his neck and be sunk to the bottom of the Sea—

Since Samuel and myself returned from Saltillo Capt. Milroy [Robert] has been there also, he returned last evening—There are no movements of the army in this quarter at present—My oppinion is that the Mexicans are so thoroughly whiped out that they will not fight us again—
Our time is nearly expired and we shall soon be discharged to go home without sharing in the honors of one victory—

The health of the Company is the best at present that it has ever been at any one time not a sick man in the Company and but few in the Regt. No camp news of any consequence except that last night Capt. Samuel and myself had a flea hunt—We killed about 250 in the blankets that we three slept in—Some of them a quarter of an inch long—Capt. is preserving a few to take home for a show—
My remembrance to your Mother, sisters and brothers.
Robert H. Milroy to Mrs. A. A. Grimes.

address.addrLine: Gen. Taylors Camp near Monteray Mexico

div.p: We received a letter a few days ago from Jim enclosing a short epistle from Marth. and a few lines from Sam. Ramey all written about the 1st of March last—

Although these letters were a long time coming and the news from home rather old, still they come to us like a refreshing shower to hot parched up country, but see here Mrs. we are not often blessed with these refreshments from you—

The last letter we received from home before the one above mentioned was in Feb. last & from Jim also so you see our refreshments from home are like angels visits—and nearly all from Jim. There was a very large mail received day before yesterday by the Regt. and almost every man in my company reed, letters except poor Sam. & me— I felt so vexed that I almost swore not to write home again but I concluded to write one more letter to set you a christian example by returning good for evil and as our time is nearly out (one month & 10 days) I will probably be able to come home & scold before I could do so again by letter— Sam. & myself and indeed every man in my company is in first rate health. The fact is the whole Regiment is now in fine health with the exception of a few men who have partly lost the use of their lower limbs but are otherwise as fat & hearty as ever they were in their lives, this was the case with two of my men that were discharged since they came up here Lewis Yost & Samuel Yeager and one of my men is affected that way now Joseph Mabbit (a nephew of old Jackys) he is as fat as a bear and as stout as a horse but it is with difficulty that he can use his legs in walking—

I have no news of any importance to write—We have the same daily routine of military duty to perform each day, the Mexicans seem to be perfectly subdued in this part of the country and mix with us and trade with us as sociably as if they never thought of war, but they are all treacherous devils and there are a great many robers among them who are sculking through the country every place. One of Capt. Lewis' men (of Fort Wayne ) by the name of George Fry was murdered 4 days ago by them% of a mile from camp he went out hunting in the afternoon and did not return that night, in the morning they sent out parties of men to hunt for him & they found him most horribly mangled, his throat was cut from ear to ear his neck had been stabed through twice and his skull broken in three places, he was brought into camp, washed and buried —The sight of the mangled bloody corps enraged the men very much and it is with difficulty that they could be restrained from killing the Mexicans that came about camp. I saw several get knocked down and kicked. Many of them will have to bite the dust before we leave Mexico— We will remain here probably till out time expires or at least till the 1st of next month. Gen. Taylor tells us that we will be discharged on this side of Camargo or Matamoras if they will have money enough there then to pay us off, if not we will be sent to N. Orleans to be discharged— I hope
we will be discharged on this side of the Gulf as I wish to travel through Texas to see the country—Yesterday was the anniversary of the battle of Palo Alto and a number of the officers of our Regt. my noble self among the rest went over to old Zacks Markee to congratulate him, which he received with much pleasure—I see him every day and have got well acquainted with him, he is a low chunky very common looking old man and I dont think him a man of superior talents by any means—We have just received today the official news of a great victory by Gen. Scott over Santa Ana, which you will have learnt before this reaches you—

Tell John that there are three of the Norwich University boys here in the army, O. A. Buck as Adjt. of the North Carolina Regt W. W. H. Davis as Adjt. of the Massachusetts Regt. & Charles Crowingshield as Capt in it—Give my love & respects to all and write soon to me at Matamoras or N. Orleans—Your Brother

div.head: Reviews and Notices

The Critical Court Struggle in Kentucky
, 1819-1829. By ARNDT M. STICKLES. Published under the auspices of the Graduate Council of Indiana University, Bloomington , 1929. Pp. 122, fifty cents in paper covers.
div.p: In his monograph of one hundred twenty-two pages, Dr. A. M. Stickles has made an interesting and important contribution to the history of Kentucky and the West. In the social and economic background of a pioneer community is set this unique struggle between the Old Court Party and the New Court Party. This struggle grew out of the broader conflict between the relief and anti-relief factions of the population, which in turn represented the debtor and the creditor classes of early Kentucky . The story involves the development of the banking system and its currency, questions of a constitutional nature and the relation of State to Federal Government. The struggle was an intense one and came to its climax after the panic of 1819, especially during the three years from 1823-1826.

In the early settlement of Kentucky , every kind of money was scarce and exchanges were made by barter or through the medium of furs, wheat or tobacco warehouse receipts. In 1802, the State Legislature chartered the Kentucky Insurance Company and its bonds, notes and bills served the purpose of a currency. In 1806, the Legislature chartered the Bank of Kentucky . The State held half of the stock, selected half of the directors and chose the President of the Bank. Although political influences affected its note issues, the Bank continued its existence until 1822 and did a good deal to tide over the war period from 1812 to 1815.

The Second United States Bank, chartered in 1816, had two branches in Kentucky but was never very popular and efforts were made to tax it out of existence but without success. The State in this attempt came better to understand its relation to the Federal Government.

The profits made by the Bank of Kentucky stimulated competition and many independent banks were chartered. These
banks stretched their credit to the limit, issuing millions of dollars in paper with a minimum of specie to back it. "Inexperience, dishonesty and mismanagement characterized their existence."

Speculation in land and abundance of products led the western population to indulge high hopes for the future and to be confident of attaining wealth. The panic of 1819 broke this bubble, and caused such distress as perhaps has never been equalled in Kentucky . Bad crops and heavy obligations to banks and merchants coming together created an emergency that tried the pioneer population to the limit.

A traveler passing through Kentucky at this time in referring to the situation speaks of "enterprize checked, commerce at a standstill and currency depreciated." Prices fell very low and sales were hard to make even then. "The whole state grew restless and county meetings to consider relief were held everywhere."

Relief became an issue in elections for governor and legislature and the advocates of relief came to control both branches of the State government. Legislation was enacted, favorable to their cause, moderate at first but more extreme later on. Debtors were permitted to replevy for three to twelve months. In 1820 a law was passed which gave a debtor two years to pay a debt after it was due. Still more radical was a law which prohibited the sale of property on court order for less than three-fourths of its value unless the creditor would take the notes of the Bank of Kentucky or the Bank of the Commonwealth. The Bank of the Commonwealth was chartered by the relief Legislature in 1820 and was a relief measure. It was backed by the sale of lands west of the Tennessee River, but it never had more than a few thousands of dollars in specie in its vaults.

The relief party controlled the legislature and the governor but the anti-relief party found support in the courts of the State. It was on account of this that the struggle ended in the courts. In 1822, James Clark, circuit judge, rendered a decision on a case that came up in Bourbon County to the effect that the law permitting replevins was contrary to both National and State Constitutions, as a violation of contract. A committee of the Legislature, appointed to investigate, reported that decision was "subversive of the best interests of the people and calculated to disturb the tranquility of the
country and shake confidence in institutions and measures of the government." Intense feeling prevailed and Judge Clark was removed although the Constitution of the State entitled a Judge to his position during good behavior. A similar decision was rendered in Fayette County by Judge Blair. The case was carried to the Court of Appeals, of which Judge John Boyle was chief Justice, and the decision of the lower court was sustained in 1823. These court decisions were not hastily arrived at but were the result of careful consideration.

Again the feeling was intense and an effort was made to remove the Judges of the Court of Appeals, but without success. The relief party then undertook to agitate for a convention to amend the State Constitution but did not succeed. The election of 1824 strengthened the relief party in the General Assembly and a law was passed by a vote of 22 to 16 to create a new Court of Appeals. The debate on this measure was one of the most prolonged, able and acrimonious in the history of Kentucky or of any other State, and both sides were championed by able men. The bill was skillfully drawn and created a Court of Appeals to consist of four judges, and with curious inconsistency the salary was increased. The positions were filled and the new court began to function. It seized the court records and bloodshed would surely have followed had an attempt to recover them been made.

Thus there were two courts in Kentucky at once, each claiming to be the legal body. Cases were carried before both courts and decisions rendered. The monograph under review by tables, shows in detail the relative amount of business done by each court as well as the support of either by counties.

The Election of 1825 was particularly exciting as each of the court parties made a desperate effort for control. All, kinds of tricks were resorted to in attempts to affect the result. Liquor, which generally flowed rather freely in those days, was so doctored that many were taken sick and kept from voting. The New Court Party was called the People's Party and the Old Court Party was dubbed the Lawyer's Party because it had the general support of the legal profession. "No popular controversy, waged without bloodshed, was ever more absorbing or acrimonious than the one which raged over Kentucky like a hurricane for three years."

In the General Assembly the Old Court Party kept gaining in each election from 1825 on, and although the struggle con-
tinued the law creating the new court was repealed and the old court assumed its former place. It started anew with a heavy docket as many cases had been allowed to wait until the struggle between the courts should run its course.

As a result of this "Critical Court Struggle," the pioneer population learned a good deal about finance which affected the future character of the State; they came to understand more clearly the relation of the State to the Federal Government, thus overcoming the separatist tendencies of earlier years.
Berea College, Berea, Kentucky .

div.head: Lincoln the Hoosier. By CHARLES GARRETT VANNEST. Eden Publishing House, St. Louis , 1928. Pp. xiii + 258. Illustrated.1
div.p: This volume treats somewhat extensively that portion of Lincoln's life which was spent in Indiana. From the age of seven to twenty-one, the child, youth, and young man was subjected to the forces included in his southwestern Indiana environment. The author declares that his purpose in writing the volume was to prove that these forces made Lincoln a Hoosier. He feels that the evidence to demonstrate this has been furnished. It seems that other writers, by placing low estimates on the value of the Indiana factors that influenced Lincoln, likewise furnished the author with a motive. He desired to prove that the youth of the man, who later become one of the world's greatest figures, was not spent in a "cramped cultural environment". The book was written with a simple formula for a guide: "Lincoln's blood and environment explain him".

Every chapter of this new work on Lincoln is interesting. No one will argue that his life in Indiana was not more deserving of a book than the subjects selected by numerous writers who have felt urgent calls to add something to the extensive literature pertaining to the great man. In the main, the author has performed his task well. He aimed at completeness, and admits in his Preface that he has "brought together all there is to be known of Lincoln's life in Indiana".

There are chapters on the ancestry of Lincoln, on his
1 This review is reprinted from the Indiana University Alumni Quarterly of April, 1829.
schooling, and on his reading habits and opportunities. The better features of the life in the community where the Lincolns lived are stressed. The physical labor which the youth was called on to perform and the great bodily strength which he developed are adequately treated. There is even a chapter on the slavery question.

The book is well worth reading, and it should be read and enjoyed by many who are interested in Lincoln. Students will find valuable information in it. One wishes that the writer had been leas anxious to prove preconceived notions. It would have been much better had he simply told his story, on the basis of his findings. His opinions and conclusions, he had a right to state, of course. Perhaps he may be correct in all of them, but the historian who pleads his cause too earnestly is not entirely convincing. The seeker for the truth can not fully approve an author who consciously sets out to prove something.

Middletown
, a volume of over five-hundred pages by Robert S. Lynd and Helen Merrill Lynd, pictures the activities —economic, political, social, religious, and cultural—of Muncie , Indiana. The volume which has proved interesting and stimulating to many readers is published by Harcourt, Brace and Company of New York City, and retails at $5.00 per copy. The introduction to the study is from the pen of Dr. Clark Wissler. Under the auspices of the Institute for Social and Religious Research, the Lynds lived for a period in our prosperous manufacturing city, which went through its first boom in the natural gas era, and studied all phases of its life. One reviwer says of the book: "Nothing like it has ever before been attempted; no such knowledge of how the average American community works and plays has ever been packed between the covers of any one book; and I warn you that hereafter nobody has any right to make the most casual generalizations about the culture levels of this republic, until he has first read and mastered his
Middletown ". (Stuart Chase, in The Nation, February 6, 1929). John Dewey correctly thinks of " Middletown " as "Anytown". In an article under the caption, "The House Divided against Itself" (New Republic, April 24, 1929), stimulated
by the reading of
Middletown
, Dewey reaches some conclusions about American life well worth repeating:
Of one thing I feel quite sure. It is not true that machinery is the source of our troubles… If we do not plan, if we do not use machinery intelligently on behalf of things we value, the fault lies with us not with the machine. This fact underlies, I suppose, the contradiction in our life; with an enormous command of instrumentalities, with possession of a secure technology, we glorify the past, and legalize and idealize the status quo, instead of seriously asking how we are to direct and employ the means at our disposal. This is our great abdication. There is a strain of fear running through American life which controls our activities to an untold extent. We dare not act lest we upset something. This state of fear will, presumably, endure until we begin to plan our living in a systematic and collected way, which means of necessity a collective way.

In a recent pamphlet (Indiana History Bulletin, volume VI, extra number 1, January, 1929), the Indiana Historical Bureau has published a second revision of Historical Markers and Public Memorials in Indiana, compiled by Jessie P. Boswell. The Bulletin is a compilation of one hundred six pages, and is illustrated by many cuts of markers, statues and memorials. The frontispiece is a picture of the chaste and beautiful Indiana World War Memorial, recently constructed by the State in Indianapolis . An attempt has been made to record the work done in the several counties of the State in the way of designating historic sites and of erecting memorials to persons and events. The head of the Historical Bureau, Dr. Christopher B. Coleman, solicits "corrections and additions" in an announcement which prefaces the pamphlet. In regard to the historical accuracy of inscriptions placed on markers, the State Bureau and the compiler of the pamphlet do not accept any responsibility. Dr. Coleman wisely says: "A careful scrutiny would doubtless show that here and there claims have been embodied in stone and bronze without sufficient warrant." It should be remembered by all local societies or committees that loyalty to truth is a more fundamental virtue than a display of patriotism to the community when based on doubtful evidence.

div.head: Comment and News
div.p: The history of almost any middle western college is well worth the writing. Several histories portraying the struggles, the near-failures, the triumphs, the changes, and the growth of certain institutions of higher learning have appeared in recent years. A number of others should follow. Many sectarian and other non-State colleges that were founded were unable to survive the vicissitudes of the times. Some of the survivals and revivals were little short of miraculous. After being saved time and again by heroic efforts, there were cases when life continued to hang only by a thread. There are those that still lead a hand to mouth existence, with meagre endowments, poor equipment, and insufficient funds with which to employ faculties.

The histories that have been written of colleges that are still going concerns have been prepared by authors who are friends of the schools dealt with. Such writers are to be commended and, as already indicated, it is to be hoped that others will follow their examples. There is a need in addition for sketches of colleges, living, dead, and near-dead from the pens of outsiders, who, though just and fair, can be entirely disinterested. These must come before we shall have any true history of college education in the Middle West.

Readers of this Magazine who are of that extremely small group of American citizens who have had the inclination to become acquainted with the larger works of American history, such as those by McMaster, Rhodes, Channing, and Oberholtzer, will be much interested in a series of articles appearing in the
Mississippi Valley Historical Review. A critical evaluation of Rhodes as a writer of history was published in the March number of the quarterly mentioned, and a similar treatment of McMaster may be found in the June number recently issued. Further articles of the same nature are to come in future issues. These valuable papers are the results of studies undertaken by graduate students in the seminar courses of Professor Jemegan of the University of Chicago .

For the year 1929, the Georgia Historical Society is offering a prize of one hundred dollars to the person submitting the best article on some subject connected with the history of Georgia . The competition is open to anyone, and the award will be announced in the March, 1930, number of the
Georgia Historical Quarterly. The announcement includes the statement: "The Society reserves the right to publish in its magazine any article submitted."

The plan here adopted to insure the writing of not merely one but several papers pertaining to the history of Georgia , is of interest to the Editor of the Indiana Magazine of History. He hopes that some generous member of the Indiana Historical Society will make it possible to announce a similar competition in this State soon. He should like to announce an offer of fifty dollars for the best article on some phase of Indiana history, with a second fifty dollars to be distributed among five of those who, though they do not win first place in the contest, submit papers suitable for publication.

This Magazine, which is published quarterly by the Department of History of Indiana University in cooperation with the Indiana Historical Society, goes to each member of the Society for the nominal sum of one dollar per year—the price of a fair dinner. It seemed to the new and unsophisticated Editor that the members of the Historical Society would be very willing to increase the annual dues by a reasonable amount, in order that the Magazine might be granted a more adequate subsidy from the Society—perhaps two dollars per member; or if not, at least one dollar and fifty cents each. When considering such a suggestion, the Executive Committee of the Society at a meeting held early in April went on record as opposed to any modification of the present arrangement. The Committee passed a motion to the effect that, "the editor of the be advised that it is the sense of the Society that its dues should in no event be increased and in no event can an appropriation of more than one dollar be made for the maintenance of the Magazine." The Editor has been in such a daze ever since, in regard to this matter, that he has performed his editorial duties with more than his usual docility and cheerfulness. He hopes in time to learn to "make bricks without straw."

The annual meeting of the Mississippi Valley Historical Association which was held at Vincennes , April 25-27, was in every way profitable and enjoyable. The papers read at the several meetings were of a high order, the attendance was good, the weather was fine, and the historic city on the Wabash did herself proud in caring for her guests. The meeting will be long remembered by those fortunate enough to have been present, as one of the best in a long line of excellent meetings.

Next year the members of the Association will gather at Chattanooga , a center of great historic interest. Located at the northern extremity of Lookout Mountain on the Tennessee at Moccasin Bend, the city selected by the Association is a splendid place for the annual meeting. In an important and beautiful part of the Mississippi Valley, Chattanooga is easily accessible from every direction by railways and automobile roads.

A few suggestions regarding contributions that may be submitted to the Magazine in the future, may be welcomed. As a rule papers written in good English with adequate references to the sources of information, can be prepared for the printer with little labor. Such changes as may be necessary are made merely for the sake of maintaining a reasonable degree of uniformity in regard to footnotes and other matters of form. Papers written hastily with no attempt to furnish references to materials used, require much work before they can be turned over to the printer. Very few writers are so expert that they can afford to submit a first draft without any revision whatever. It is usually much better to revise the original copy carefully one or more times, and then have a final copy prepared for submission. There is no iron-clad rule, but it is customary to avoid the first person when writing historical articles, except in papers pertaining to the family of the writer or to intimate personal matter such as holds a place in reminiscences or autobiography. In all other historical writing, it is better to present the narrative in the third person, unless there is some very specific reason for variation. Unusual care should be used in the spelling of names of persona and places, since it is frequently difficult for anyone other than the author of a paper to correct such errors even when suspected.
